Ever stood in front of the mirror, wondering why that “universally flattering” haircut looks more like a “universal disaster” on you? The secret’s in your face shape, gents. And if your jaw’s wider than your forehead with a narrower chin, congrats—you’re rocking the pear face shape. This is a good thing, and we’ll tell you exactly why. Read on. Understanding your face shape isn’t just grooming trivia; it’s your personal style GPS. It guides everything from your haircut to your shades, making the difference between “Who’s that guy?” and “Who dressed that guy?” For you pear-faced fellows, we’re about to turn your distinct features from a styling puzzle into your greatest asset. So, whether you’re aiming for a head-turning haircut or wondering why your beard isn’t quite right, you’re in the right place. Let’s dive into the world of pear-shaped perfection and have you loving what you see in the mirror. Other Face Shapes Before we explore pear face shapes for men, why not discover other face shapes or learn how to identify your own face shape and choose the perfect haircut? Understanding the nuances of your face shape can revolutionize your styling choices, leading to more flattering and suitable hairstyles. Different Face Shapes For Men Triangle Face Shape Heart Face Shape Rectangle Face Shape Oval Face Shape Oblong Face Shape Square Face Shape Round Face Shape Diamond Face Shape In This ArticleFace Shape Cheat SheetHow To Tell Your Face ShapeHairstylesBeard StylesMustache Styles SunglassesRecommended ProductsWhat's NextFAQs “Justin Timberlake Cannes 2016 – 2” by Georges Biard is licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0. Pear Face Shape Cheat Codes For those short on time but big on style: Your pear-shaped face is characterized by a wider jawline tapering to a narrower forehead and chin. To balance this, opt for hairstyles that add volume on top and at the crown, like a textured quiff. When it comes to eyewear, aviators or oversized round frames are your friends. They complement your strong jawline while softening angular features. Quick Tips for Pear Face Shape Prioritize volume in your hairstyles, especially at the crown, to balance your facial proportions. Embrace facial hair, with fuller beards helping to balance out your wider jaw. Choose wider frame glasses or oversized round frames to create harmony with your jawline. V-neck tops can help elongate your neck and balance your jawline. “File:Egdar Ramirez 2012.jpg” by Georges Biard is licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0. What Is a Pear Face Shape? Picture an inverted triangle, or indeed, a pear. Your jaw takes center stage, broader than your forehead, with cheekbones playing a supporting role in between. The key characteristic is a narrow chin, distinguishing it from other face shapes. This face shape exudes strength and character and is often associated with a masculine appearance. “DJ KHALED Press exclusive -1 (cropped)” by Dapper Lou / Sony Music Entertainment is licensed under CC BY 4.0. How to Tell That You Have a Pear Face Shape Time for some face geometry. Grab a flexible tape measure, and let’s get down to business: Face Length: Measure from your hairline to your chin tip. Forehead Width: Measure across the widest part of your forehead. Cheekbone Width: Measure from the outer point of one cheekbone to the other. Jawline Width: Measure from the tip of your chin to below your ear, then double it. If your jawline measurement is the largest, followed by your cheekbones, with your forehead being the narrowest, and you have a narrow chin, then you’re likely sporting a pear-shaped face. “Keith Urban” by Frank Roche is licensed under CC BY-NC 2.0. Let’s explore some styles that’ll have you looking sharp: Textured Quiff: The Height of Style masonjameshair / Instagram A textured quiff can create the illusion of a longer face, perfectly complementing a pear shape. The added height helps to balance out the wider jawline characteristic of this face shape. Why it works: This style adds height and volume on top, balancing out a wider jawline. Just ask Beckham. Styling tips: Keep the top longer and texturized for maximum volume. Add extra volume at the crown. Taper the sides for a slimming effect. Use a matte product for a natural, effortless finish. Side-Swept Undercut: The Best of Both Worlds menshairstyles / Instagram This style creates visual interest on top while slimming the sides, helping to balance out a wider jawline characteristic of pear face shapes. Benefits: It creates asymmetry and draws attention upward, away from a wider jaw. This certainly worked for Kevin Bacon. Remember him? How to style: Keep the top longer and sweep it to one side. Undercut the sides for a striking contrast. Use a medium-hold product for all-day staying power. Modern Comb-over: Sleek and Sophisticated brightbazaar / Instagram This style’s deep side-part and added height elongate the face, counterbalancing the stronger jaw typical of pear-shaped faces. Perfect for: Adding height and drawing attention away from the jawline. How to achieve: Keep hair longer on top and shorter on the sides. Part hair deeply to one side. Use a strong-hold pomade for a polished look. Pompadour: Go Big or Go Home “James Dean” by twm1340 is licensed under CC BY-SA 2.0. By adding significant volume and height at the crown, the pompadour creates a striking vertical line that offsets the width of a pear-shaped face’s jawline. Why it’s great: It adds significant height to balance out a stronger jaw. This look heightened James Dean’s appeal. Styling steps: Grow out the top section longer than the sides. Blow-dry for maximum volume and shape, especially at the crown. Use a strong-hold pomade to keep everything in place. Layered Mid-Length Style: Versatile Vibes zeno_vic / Instagram This versatile cut adds width to the upper part of the face through strategic layering, creating balance with the naturally wider lower half of a pear-shaped face. Why it works: It adds width to the upper part of your face while offering styling flexibility. Styling tips: Ask for layers to add volume and movement. Keep some length around the ears to balance face width. Use a lightweight styling cream for definition without heaviness. Remember, the key for pear face shapes is to add volume up top and at the crown while keeping the sides relatively neat. This creates a balancing effect with your stronger jawline. Always chat with your stylist to find the perfect variation of these styles for your unique features and hair type. Beard Styles for Pear Face Shapes: Sculpting Your Canvas When it comes to facial hair for pear face shapes, the goal is to maintain your strong jawline while adding some balance to your upper face. Fuller beards can be particularly beneficial in balancing out your wider jaw. Let’s explore some beard styles that’ll have you looking like you’ve got a personal barber on speed dial. The Full Beard: Balanced Sophistication menbeardstyles / Instagram A full beard can add maturity and style to a pear face shape. Remember to keep it well-groomed to complement, not compete with, your jawline. The cheeks’ fullness helps balance out the wider jaw, creating a more harmonious overall appearance. Why it works: It adds dimension to your face and helps balance the wider jawline. Grooming tips: Grow your beard for 4–6 weeks before shaping. Keep the length fuller on the cheeks and chin. Trim regularly to maintain a neat, groomed appearance. Use beard balm for control and conditioning. The Short Stubble: Rugged Minimalism melvillestephen / Instagram Short stubble can enhance your jawline without adding bulk. It’s like contouring for men but much easier to achieve. This style works well for those who want to maintain a rugged look without committing to a full beard. George Clooney has run the gamut of facial hair styles in his time, but nobody does short stubble quite like he does. Why it works: It adds texture without overpowering your natural face shape. Grooming tips: Keep your beard trimmer set between 2 and 4 mm. Maintain clean, defined edges along your jawline. Use beard oil to keep skin and hair healthy. The Goatee: Focus on the Middle “Leonardo DiCaprio avp 2013 3” by Georges Biard is licensed under CC BY-SA 3.0. A well-groomed goatee can add character to a pear-shaped face without emphasizing jaw width. It helps to create a focal point in the center of your face, drawing attention away from the wider jawline. Benefits: Draws attention to the center of your face, balancing out a wider jaw. Among the famous men sporting goatees in recent years are Chris Hemsworth and Leonardo DiCaprio. How to achieve and maintain: Grow out your facial hair for about two weeks. Shape a circle connecting your mustache to your chin hair. Keep the cheeks clean-shaven. Trim regularly to maintain a neat, defined shape. Mustache Styles: The Upper Lip Upgrade For pear face shapes, the right mustache can add a touch of sophistication while balancing your facial proportions. Let’s explore some ‘stache styles that’ll have you looking dapper: The Chevron: Classic Cool manandhismustache / Instagram This classic mustache style adds width to the upper lip, creating a visual counterpoint to the wider jawline typical of pear-shaped faces. Why it works: It adds width to your upper lip, helping to balance out a stronger jaw. It definitely worked for Freddie Mercury. Grooming tips: Allow 4–6 weeks of growth for full coverage. Keep the edges aligned with the corners of your mouth. Trim along your lipline daily for a neat appearance. Product suggestion: Try a quality mustache wax to keep those hairs in line without the dreaded “crunch” effect. The Handlebar: Quirky Charm stylish_mustache_men / Instagram With its upward-curling ends, the handlebar mustache does you a solid, helping to balance the proportions of a pear-shaped face. Benefits: This style adds width to your upper face, creating a playful contrast with your jawline. How to style: Grow your mustache for several months to achieve the necessary length. Use a strong hold wax to train the ends upward. Comb through daily to distribute natural oils and maintain shape. Pro tip: Aim for a wider handlebar for pear faces to help visually broaden your upper face. The Pyramid: Balanced Sophistication must_tache / Instagram This sophisticated style’s broad base and tapered top add structure to the upper lip, complementing the natural contours of a pear-shaped face. Perfect for: Adding structure to your upper lip while complementing your face shape. How to achieve: Grow your mustache for 1–2 months. Shape it into a broad base tapering to a point just under the nose. Trim regularly to maintain the pyramid shape. Must-have tool: Invest in a good-quality beard trimmer with multiple length settings for precise shaping. Sunglasses for Pear Face Shapes: Shade Your Way to Style When it comes to sunglasses for pear face shapes, it’s all about drawing attention upward and adding width to your forehead area. Let’s dive into the styles that’ll have you looking like you’ve stepped straight off a runway. Aviators: Top Gun Approved Aviators are incredibly versatile for pear face shapes. They add width where you need it, at the forehead and temples, and the tapered bottom complements your natural face shape. Why they work: The wide upper portion and tapered bottom complement your face shape perfectly. And they certainly can help you fly a Super Hornet jet. Style tip: Opt for slightly oversized frames to maximize the widening effect on your forehead. Wayfarers: Retro Cool, Modern You With their bold upper frame, Wayfarers create a strong horizontal line across the forehead, balancing out the wider jawline characteristic of pear-shaped faces. Benefits: The bold upper frame adds width to your forehead, and the straight brow line contrasts nicely with your jaw. Fashion forward: Try colored or patterned frames to add a contemporary twist to this classic style. Oversized Round Frames: Softening Touch Why they’re great: They add structure to your upper face while softening angular features. Style it up: Choose frames with some detailing on the upper portion to draw the eye upward. Remember, sunglasses are an essential accessory that can significantly impact your overall look. For pear shapes, they’re not just a fashion statement but also a tool to balance your facial proportions. If you choose wisely, they’ll become your secret weapon for achieving facial harmony. Beard: Honest Amish Beard Balm—ideal for maintaining fuller beards that balance your face shape. Skin: Lab Series Age Rescue Face Lotion—keep that skin looking as sharp as your jawline. Sunglasses: Ray-Ban Original Aviator—timeless style for your timeless good looks. Grooming Tool: BaBylissPRO FX—for precision in all your facial hair endeavors and especially useful for maintaining beard fullness on the cheeks. Mustache: Death Grip Mustache Wax—for when you want that mustache to keep its shape. What’s Next? Understanding your pear-shaped face is the first step toward enhancing your personal style and accentuating your best features. Don’t stop there—explore how different collar styles, neckties, and even beard shapes can further complement your face shape. Remember, grooming extends beyond the face—consider how your clothing choices, particularly shoulder width and necklines, can balance your overall look. Remember, gents, your pear-shaped face is a unique asset. With these tips in your style arsenal, you’re well on your way to turning heads for all the right reasons. Now go forth and rock that chiseled jawline with confidence! FAQ There’s very little difference—both terms describe a face that’s wider at the jaw than at the forehead. The key distinction is that a pear shape typically has a narrower chin than a triangle shape. Absolutely. For those short on time but big on style: Your pear-shaped face is characterized by a wider jawline tapering to a narrower forehead and chin. To balance this, opt for hairstyles that add volume on top and at the crown, like a textured quiff. When it comes to eyewear, aviators or oversized round frames are your friends. They complement your strong jawline while softening angular features.

Quick Tips for Pear Face Shape

  • Prioritize volume in your hairstyles, especially at the crown, to balance your facial proportions.
  • Embrace facial hair, with fuller beards helping to balance out your wider jaw.
  • Choose wider frame glasses or oversized round frames to create harmony with your jawline.
  • V-neck tops can help elongate your neck and balance your jawline.

What Is a Pear Face Shape?

Picture an inverted triangle, or indeed, a pear. Your jaw takes center stage, broader than your forehead, with cheekbones playing a supporting role in between.

The key characteristic is a narrow chin, distinguishing it from other face shapes. This face shape exudes strength and character and is often associated with a masculine appearance.

How to Tell That You Have a Pear Face Shape

Time for some face geometry. Grab a flexible tape measure, and let’s get down to business:

  1. Face Length: Measure from your hairline to your chin tip.
  2. Forehead Width: Measure across the widest part of your forehead.
  3. Cheekbone Width: Measure from the outer point of one cheekbone to the other.
  4. Jawline Width: Measure from the tip of your chin to below your ear, then double it.

If your jawline measurement is the largest, followed by your cheekbones, with your forehead being the narrowest, and you have a narrow chin, then you’re likely sporting a pear-shaped face.

Hairstyles for Pear Face Shapes: Balancing Act

When styling hair for a pear face shape, the goal is to add volume on top and at the crown while keeping the sides relatively slim. Let’s explore some styles that’ll have you looking sharp:

Textured Quiff: The Height of Style

A textured quiff can create the illusion of a longer face, perfectly complementing a pear shape. The added height helps to balance out the wider jawline characteristic of this face shape.

Why it works: This style adds height and volume on top, balancing out a wider jawline. Just ask Beckham.

Styling tips:

  • Keep the top longer and texturized for maximum volume.
  • Add extra volume at the crown.
  • Taper the sides for a slimming effect.
  • Use a matte product for a natural, effortless finish.

Side-Swept Undercut: The Best of Both Worlds

This style creates visual interest on top while slimming the sides, helping to balance out a wider jawline characteristic of pear face shapes.

Benefits: It creates asymmetry and draws attention upward, away from a wider jaw. This certainly worked for Kevin Bacon. Remember him?

How to style:

  • Keep the top longer and sweep it to one side.
  • Undercut the sides for a striking contrast.
  • Use a medium-hold product for all-day staying power.

Modern Comb-over: Sleek and Sophisticated

This style’s deep side-part and added height elongate the face, counterbalancing the stronger jaw typical of pear-shaped faces.

Perfect for: Adding height and drawing attention away from the jawline.

How to achieve:

  • Keep hair longer on top and shorter on the sides.
  • Part hair deeply to one side.
  • Use a strong-hold pomade for a polished look.

Pompadour: Go Big or Go Home

By adding significant volume and height at the crown, the pompadour creates a striking vertical line that offsets the width of a pear-shaped face’s jawline.

Styling steps:

  • Grow out the top section longer than the sides.

  • Use a strong-hold pomade to keep everything in place.

Layered Mid-Length Style: Versatile Vibes

This versatile cut adds width to the upper part of the face through strategic layering, creating balance with the naturally wider lower half of a pear-shaped face.

Why it works: It adds width to the upper part of your face while offering styling flexibility.

Beard Styles for Pear Face Shapes: Sculpting Your Canvas
